weeklyGoal.q1: I want to feel more confident and prepared in advisor meetings.
weeklyGoal.q2: I often feel nervous and forget to ask questions or explain things clearly.

action: Write 3 main updates and questions before meetings
Bring a visual summary of key points
Start the meeting with a clear agenda
Take notes on what feedback I get
focus: Pay attention to where my advisor seems confused
Notice when I rush or lose focus
Watch for nonverbal cues like nodding or frowning
Track whether I'm listening or zoning out
Notice how I respond under pressure
interpretation: Advisor wants me to lead the meeting, not just report
Feeling nervous doesn't mean I'm unprepared
It's okay to ask again if I don't understand
response: Take a breath if I feel overwhelmed
Keep a calm, open body posture
Pause instead of rushing to respond

dailyReflection.text0: I ran into my advisor unexpectedly and decided to share some updates.
dailyReflection.text1: I quickly summarized what I had worked on but forgot to mention key parts.
dailyReflection.text2: She said I should clarify certain sections and looked a bit distracted.
dailyReflection.text3: I thought she wa't interested and felt like I failed to present well.
dailyReflection.text4: I felt embarrassed afterward and avoided reviewing the feedback for hours.

generatedCfTexts: I decided to wait until our scheduled meeting instead.
I sent her an email summarizing my updates in advance.
I asked if now was a good time before jumping in.
I reviewed my notes before deciding whether to approach.
I mentally rehearsed the key points before initiating.
I opened with one strong takeaway before explaining details.
I asked her what she wanted to hear most about.
I shared a visual summary of the progress made so far.
I paused and asked if she had a few minutes first.
I walked through the key points slowly and confidently.
I watched her face to see what confused her most.
I focused on staying calm and engaged instead of overthinking.
I reminded myself to track which feedback felt unclear.
I noted which updates made her lean in or look curious.
I observed how she responded when I paused.
I reminded myself she might be preoccupied, not uninterested.
I interpreted her feedback as helpful, not dismissive.
I told myself the effort still mattered even if the delivery was rough.
I assumed she wanted more details rather than less.
I viewed the chat as a quick touchpoint, not a full review.
I reviewed her feedback later and wrote down two key notes.
I told myself I could apply this next time instead of spiraling.
I reached out to a peer for perspective and support.
I reminded myself that awkward moments happen and moved on.
I paused for a moment, smiled, and got back to work.
